Hello, and welcome
to another episode

of Managing Through Crisis,
where Harvard Business School

faculty share their
insights on how
to manage in challenging times.

in 2020 at the beginning

of the pandemic,

were unprecedented
times for managers.

a constant in business.

So we continue to post episodes
on things like supply chain

and other things that have
happened in the business world.

thrilled to be speaking

with Professor John Quelch,

Dean of Miami Business School.

buying patterns.

essentially the population

spending almost overnight.

necessary items continue

people do not stop

predictable approaches

Yeah, so we've talked
about consumers
in this kind of environment.

cut, and slash, and control

this environment,

what kind of argument

budget should not
be on the cutting block?

have products that

have been accelerating in

pull the rug out

to potentially pick up more

Yeah, so it sounds like

strategically important areas?

family businesses, large-scale
family businesses that are well

from the stock market, these
companies take a long view

invest significant cash

in the acquisition of weaker

private companies

the chief financial officer.

bane of existence

environment.

fast-moving consumer goods

effects, if you like,

that stem from first of all,

that sequence still
holds true even today

and leveraging digital media

to generate these
effects among consumers.

conversation, John.

now after hearing
you talk about this.

tendency for people

to think about doom and gloom

But it sounds like
there's real opportunity

here in the marketing
function to be able to thrive

to move forward
in a recessionary environment?

Number one is exactly
what you said, Brian,

moral obligation

of every chief marketing
officer to remain optimistic
